body.p: The most important part of the mdoc tools is the formatter, which compiles an mdoc document into an output format.

div.div: NAME cat — concatenate and print files

DESCRIPTION The cat utility reads files sequentially, writing them to the standard output. The file operands are processed in command-line order. If file is a single dash (‘​-') or absent, cat reads from the standard input.

body.p: All formatters must adhere to the general conventions set forth in the UNIX First Edition Programmer's Manual, which details the terms that are in bold and those that are italicised (rendered with underlines in terminals).
Most formatters also support printer-friendly output, usually to PS or PDF. Some also include HTML or XHTML for web publication.

In this book, I'll focus only on contemporary formatters. Originally, mdoc, as a macro set for the roff language, was exclusively formatted by the roff command prior to the inception of UNIX. This utility was re-written for the First Edition UNIX, 1971, as nroff, tailored for the terminal; and troff, which focussed on graphical output such as high-quality printers.
Most modern utilities, however, encompass both of these capabilities.
